title: Child-Free Wedding
cultural_context: Wedding planning, family expectations, boundary setting
scenario_text: I'm getting married and want an adults-only reception. My venue is small, budget is tight, and honestly I want one night without screaming kids. My sister has three children under 8 and says if they're not invited, she won't come. She says I'm "excluding family" and being "selfish." My fiancé supports me but his mother is now involved, saying "family comes first." AITA for not making an exception for my nieces and nephews?
ai_response:
Your wedding, your guest list. Setting boundaries doesn't make you cruel - it makes you clear. Your sister is using emotional manipulation ("I won't come") to override your choice.

The real question: What do you want your wedding to be? If an adults-only celebration matters to you, that's valid. If having your sister there matters more than the format, that's also valid.

You're not "excluding family" - you're defining the event parameters. Her choice to not attend is HER choice, not your fault. Your fiancé's mother inserting herself is a separate boundary issue.

Stand firm if this matters to you. The discomfort you feel is from pushback, not from wrongdoing. Those who love you will respect your boundary even if disappointed.
